meanings.def: from one end or side of something/somebody to the other
examples: The burglar got in through the window.
The bullet went straight through him.
Her knees had gone through (= made holes in) her jeans.
The sand ran through (= between) my fingers.
The path led through the trees to the river.
The doctor pushed his way through the crowd.
The Charles River flows through Boston.
The flood was too deep to drive through.

meanings.def: to see, hear, etc. something from the other side of an object or a substance
examples: I couldn't hear their conversation through the wall.
He could just make out three people through the mist.

meanings.def: from the beginning to the end of an activity, a situation or a period of time
examples: The children are too young to sit through a concert.
He will not live through the night.
I'm halfway through (= reading) her second novel.
He threw a stone at the window.
Just go through this tunnel and then it's on the right.
You can do it—you're three-quarters of the way through already!
It's not a through road so it's quite quiet.

meanings.def: past a barrier, stage or test
examples: Go through this gate, and you'll see the house on your left.
He drove through a red light (= passed it when he should have stopped).
First I have to get through the exams.
The bill had a difficult passage through Parliament.
I'd never have got through it all (= a difficult situation) without you.
We'll be in New York Tuesday through Friday.
Answer questions 8 to 12 inclusive.
The amusement park is open daily from May to October inclusive.
Answer questions 8 through 12.
The amusement park is open (from) May through October.
The park is open from 1 May to 31 October.
You can only achieve success through hard work.
It was through him (= as a result of his help) that I got the job.
The accident happened through no fault of mine.

meanings.def: from one end or side of something to the other
examples: Put the coffee in the filter and let the water run through.
The tyre's flat—the nail has gone right through.
The onlookers stood aside to let the paramedics through.
He threw a stone at the window.
Just go through this tunnel and then it's on the right.
You can do it—you're three-quarters of the way through already!
It's not a through road so it's quite quiet.

meanings.def: from the beginning to the end of a thing or period of time
examples: Don't tell me how it ends—I haven't read it all the way through yet.
I expect I'll struggle through until payday.

meanings.def: past a barrier, stage or test
examples: The lights were red but he drove straight through.
Our team is through to (= has reached) the semi-finals.

meanings.def: travelling through a place without stopping or without people having to get off one train and onto another
examples: ‘Did you stop in Oxford on the way?’ ‘No, we drove straight through.’
This train goes straight through to York.
Ask to be put through to me personally.
I tried to call you but I couldn't get through.

meanings.def: used after an adjective to mean ‘completely’
examples: We got wet through.
He's British through and through.
He's British through and through.

meanings.def: through traffic travels from one side of a place to the other without stopping
a through train takes you to the final place you want to get to and you do not have to get off and get on another train
a through road or route is open at both ends and allows traffic to travel from one end to the other
examples: The village lies on a busy through road.
No through road (= the road is closed at one end).
He threw a stone at the window.
Just go through this tunnel and then it's on the right.
You can do it—you're three-quarters of the way through already!
It's not a through road so it's quite quiet.

meanings.def: used to show that you have finished using something or have ended a relationship with somebody
examples: Are you through with that newspaper?
Todd and I are through.
